Watch for their habit of feeding on tree buds and fruit. Their tendency to visit feeders regularly in some areas makes them relatively easy to observe, though they can be confused with the similar House Finch.

shortDesc: A swallow that is pretty much an irridescent purple/blue.
longDesc: The Purple Martin is the largest North American swallow. Adult males are entirely deep purple-blue and glossy, while females and immatures are duller with gray-brown upperparts and lighter underparts. They have a forked tail and long, pointed wings. Their flight is swift and graceful, with periods of gliding. Their voice is a rich, gurgling chirp, often given in flight. During breeding season, males sing a dawn song, a series of low, liquid chirps and gurgles.
howToFind: Purple Martins are often found near human habitations, especially in eastern North America where they nest almost exclusively in man-made housing. Look for martin houses or gourds in open areas near water. These large swallows are often seen soaring and swooping high in the air, catching insects on the wing. Listen for their rich, gurgling songs and loud, descent call notes. During migration, they may gather in large roosts, sometimes numbering in the thousands. In western North America, check for them nesting in woodpecker holes or natural cavities in trees near open areas. Their social nature and reliance on human-provided nest sites in many areas make them relatively easy to find during the breeding season.

shortDesc: Nuthatch with blue back and wings, as well as a brown cap.
longDesc: The Pygmy Nuthatch is a tiny, energetic bird with a blue-gray back, buffy underparts, and a brownish cap. It has a short tail and a straight, pointed bill. Unlike other nuthatches, it lacks a dark eye-line. These social birds are often seen in small flocks, moving acrobatically through pine trees. Their calls are a series of high-pitched, squeaky notes, often described as sounding like rubber ducks. They also make a soft, rolling trill.
howToFind: Pygmy Nuthatches inhabit pine forests, particularly those dominated by ponderosa pine. Look for these tiny, energetic birds foraging in small flocks, often moving acrobatically along branches and pine cones. Listen for their high-pitched, squeaky calls, which they give almost constantly as they forage. During breeding season, check for their cavity nests in dead pines or snags. These social birds often roost communally in tree cavities, so watch for groups entering roost sites at dusk. Their small size and quick movements can make them challenging to spot, but their constant vocalizations help in locating flocks. Focus on the outer branches of mature pines, where they spend much of their time foraging.

shortDesc: Yes, their bill literally crosses each other.
longDesc: The Red Crossbill is a stocky finch with a uniquely adapted bill - the tips of the upper and lower mandibles cross over each other, an adaptation for extracting seeds from conifer cones. Males are brick-red or orange-red, while females are yellowish-olive. Both sexes have dark wings without wing bars. Their call is a sharp, metallic "kip-kip-kip," often given in flight. They also have a warbling song. Interestingly, there are several types of Red Crossbills that differ slightly in call notes and bill size, each specialized for different conifer species.
howToFind: Red Crossbills are nomadic finches found in coniferous forests, their movements largely dictated by cone crop availability. Look for them feeding on pine, spruce, or fir cones, using their uniquely crossed bills to extract seeds. These chunky finches are often detected first by their distinctive "jip-jip" flight calls. Males are brick-red, while females are yellowish-olive. Watch for their habit of hanging upside down on cones while feeding. During irruption years, they may appear in unexpected locations, including deciduous woods or suburban areas. Their tendency to visit mineral sources like road salt or grit can make them easier to spot. Scanning the tops of conifers and listening for their calls are key to finding these wandering finches.

shortDesc: They are knot to be messed with.
longDesc: The Red Knot is a large, stocky sandpiper with a straight bill about as long as its head. In breeding plumage, it lives up to its name with a rusty-red face, breast, and underparts. In winter, it's plain gray above and white below. In all plumages, it has a pale eyebrow and greenish legs. In flight, it shows a pale wing stripe. Its call is a soft "whet-whet" or "toodle-ip."
howToFind: Red Knots are best seen during migration along coastal areas. Look for them on sandy beaches, mudflats, and rocky shorelines. These robust sandpipers gather in large flocks during spring and fall migration. In breeding plumage, they have a distinctive rusty-red coloration. Watch for their feeding behavior of probing in wet sand or mud with their straight bills. During migration stopovers, they can be seen in massive flocks at key sites. Use a spotting scope to observe their behavior and plumage details from a distance. Listen for their soft, grunting calls given in flight. Timing is crucial for seeing Red Knots, as they may only be present for short periods at stopover sites during their long-distance migrations.

shortDesc: A duck with a mohawk.
longDesc: The Red-breasted Merganser is a slim diving duck with a long, thin, serrated bill adapted for catching fish. Males in breeding plumage have a dark green head with a shaggy crest, a white neck ring, and a rusty-red breast. Females and non-breeding males are gray with a rusty-brown head and a shaggy crest. Both sexes have red eyes and red bills. In flight, they show large white wing patches. Their call is a harsh, grating "karr-karr."
howToFind: Red-breasted Mergansers are found on coastal waters and large inland lakes. During breeding season, look for them on northern lakes and rivers. In winter, they gather in coastal bays and estuaries. These sleek, fish-eating ducks are often seen in small groups, diving frequently. Watch for their distinctive shaggy crest and thin, serrated bill. In flight, note their long, low profile over the water. During courtship in spring, observe their elaborate displays on the water. Use a spotting scope for better views, as they often stay far from shore. Their habit of forming long lines when fishing cooperatively can make them more noticeable. Check river mouths and sheltered coves where fish concentrate.

shortDesc: This nuthatch has a red chest and belly as well as blueish wings.
longDesc: The Red-breasted Nuthatch is a dapper little bird, sporting a smart black cap and eye stripe that contrast beautifully with its white eyebrow and cheek. True to its name, its underparts are washed with a warm rusty hue, though females may show a more subdued buff color. These industrious birds are constantly on the move, working their way down tree trunks in search of insects. Their distinctive nasal, yammering call of "ank, ank, ank" is a familiar sound in coniferous forests.
howToFind: Red-breasted Nuthatches inhabit coniferous and mixed forests, often moving into more varied habitats during winter. Listen for their distinctive, nasal "yank-yank" calls, which sound like tiny tin horns. Look for these small, agile birds creeping headfirst down tree trunks and along branches. They're frequent visitors to bird feeders, especially those offering sunflower seeds or suet. During irruption years, they may appear in large numbers in areas south of their typical range. Watch for their habit of plastering pitch around their nest hole entrances. Their bold behavior and tendency to join mixed-species foraging flocks make them relatively easy to observe once located.

shortDesc: A black woodpecker with a red head.
longDesc: The Red-breasted Sapsucker is a striking woodpecker, easily identified by its vibrant red head and breast contrasting with a black back and white wing patches. This medium-sized bird has a long, chisel-like bill perfect for its sap-feeding habits. Its most distinctive feature is the vertical rows of neatly drilled holes, or sap wells, it creates in tree bark. These wells serve as a food source not only for the sapsucker but also for other wildlife. The bird's call is a nasal, cat-like "mew" sound, while its drumming pattern is slower and more irregular compared to other woodpeckers.
howToFind: Red-breasted Sapsuckers are found in coniferous and mixed forests of the Pacific Northwest. Look for their distinctive rows of small, neatly drilled holes on tree trunks, which they visit regularly to feed on sap and trapped insects. Listen for their cat-like mewing calls and their slow, rhythmic drumming. During breeding season, check for their nest cavities in dead or dying trees. These woodpeckers are often seen clinging to tree trunks or flying with their characteristic undulating pattern. In winter, they may move to lower elevations and can be found in parks and orchards. Their habit of maintaining and revisiting sap wells makes their presence more predictable than many woodpeckers.

shortDesc: A vireo with a red eye.
longDesc: The Red-eyed Vireo is a small but vocal songbird, known as the "preacher bird" due to its near-constant singing during the breeding season. Despite its name, the red eyes are often difficult to see in the field. This bird has a olive-green back, white underparts, and a distinctive white eyebrow stripe bordered by dark lines. The crown is blue-gray, providing a subtle contrast to its overall coloration. Its song is a series of short, robin-like phrases with a questioning lilt at the end, often described as "Here I am. Where are you? Over here. In the tree."
howToFind: Red-eyed Vireos inhabit deciduous and mixed forests, often high in the canopy. These birds are more often heard than seen, so listen for their persistent, sing-song phrases that sound like "Here I am. Where are you?" repeated endlessly throughout the day. Look for movement high in leafy trees as they forage for insects along branches and leaves. During migration, they can be found lower in trees and shrubs. Watch for their deliberate movements and habit of pausing to scan leaves for prey. Their olive-green plumage and red eyes can be challenging to see in the dense foliage, so patience and careful observation are key. Focus on the mid to upper levels of deciduous trees in mature forests.

shortDesc: Black-and-white woodpecker with some red in its head.
longDesc: The Red-naped Sapsucker is a woodpecker species characterized by its striking plumage. Males sport a red crown, nape, and throat, while females have a white throat with a red nape. Both sexes have a black back with a prominent white wing patch and a pale yellow belly. Like its relatives, this sapsucker creates distinctive rows of small holes in tree bark to access sap and attract insects. Their call is a sharp, cat-like "mew," similar to other sapsuckers, and they also produce a slow, rhythmic drumming sound on resonant tree trunks or branches.
howToFind: Red-naped Sapsuckers inhabit aspen groves and mixed coniferous-deciduous forests in western mountains. Look for their distinctive rows of small, neatly drilled holes on tree trunks, which they visit regularly to feed on sap. Listen for their cat-like mewing calls and their quick, stuttering drum rolls. During breeding season, check for their nest cavities in aspen trees or other softwoods. These woodpeckers are often seen clinging to tree trunks or flying with their characteristic undulating pattern. In winter, they may move to lower elevations and can be found in orchards and parks. Their tendency to maintain and revisit sap wells makes their presence more predictable than many woodpeckers. Focus on areas with abundant aspen trees, particularly near water sources.

shortDesc: Blackish brown-and white shorebird with some red on the neck.
longDesc: The Red-necked Phalarope is a small, delicate shorebird with a unique twist - it's more at home swimming than wading. In breeding plumage, it sports a dark gray cap, white cheeks, and a distinctive chestnut-red neck patch. Its body is pale gray above and white below, with a needle-like bill. Interestingly, female Red-necked Phalaropes are more brightly colored than males, a reversal of the usual pattern in birds. These birds are known for their peculiar feeding behavior - they spin rapidly in shallow water to create a vortex that brings small aquatic prey to the surface. Their call is a sharp, metallic "pit" or "pick" often given in flight.
howToFind: Red-necked Phalaropes breed in the Arctic tundra but are more easily seen during migration on both coastal and inland waters. Look for them spinning rapidly in circles on the water's surface, a unique feeding behavior that creates a vortex bringing small prey items to the surface. During migration, check saline lakes, coastal estuaries, and even flooded fields. These small, delicate shorebirds often gather in large flocks during stopover periods. Use a spotting scope for better views, as they often stay far from shore. In pelagic areas, they may be seen in large numbers far out at sea. Listen for their short, sharp "pit" calls given in flight. Their unique swimming behavior and tendency to gather in tight flocks make them relatively easy to identify once located.

shortDesc: A hawk with some red on the chest and shoulders.
longDesc: The Red-shouldered Hawk is a medium-sized raptor known for its striking appearance and vocal nature. Adults have rich, reddish-brown barring on their breast and belly, contrasting with their dark back and wings. The species gets its name from the russet-colored shoulders visible when perched. In flight, they display translucent crescents near their wingtips, creating a distinctive pattern. Their call is a loud, descending "kee-yer," often repeated several times, which echoes through their woodland habitats. These hawks are skilled hunters, capable of catching prey in flight or pouncing from a perch.
howToFind: Look for Red-shouldered Hawks in deciduous and mixed forests, particularly near water sources like streams or swamps. They're often seen perched on branches in the mid-canopy of trees. Listen for their distinctive "kee-aah" call, which they use frequently. During breeding season, watch for their circular soaring displays over their territory. In suburban areas, they may hunt from utility poles or wires. Scan the edges of woodlands and riparian corridors, especially in early morning or late afternoon when they're most active.

shortDesc: This is a brown hawk with some red on its tail.
longDesc: The Red-tailed Hawk is one of North America's most common and recognizable raptors. True to its name, adults sport a distinctive rusty-red tail, though this is not always visible when perched. Their plumage can vary, but most have rich brown upperparts and pale underparts with a streaked belly. In flight, look for the dark bar between shoulder and wrist on the wing's leading edge. These large hawks have a wingspan of about four feet and are often seen soaring in wide circles over open areas.
howToFind: Red-tailed Hawks are adaptable and can be found in a variety of open habitats. Look for them perched on tall trees, utility poles, or fence posts along roadsides and field edges. They're often seen soaring in wide circles high overhead, especially on warm days with good thermals. Listen for their raspy, descending "kree-eee-ar" scream. During migration, watch for them at hawk watch sites. In urban areas, scan tall buildings where they sometimes nest. Their tendency to perch conspicuously makes them one of the easier raptors to spot.

shortDesc: Its name is itself the short description.
longDesc: Red-winged Blackbirds are always a treat to observe. Males are glossy black all over, save for the brilliant red and yellow epaulets on their shoulders that give the species its name. These colorful patches become particularly vibrant during displays. Females, often mistaken for large, brown-streaked sparrows, have a subtler beauty with their brown and buff streaked plumage. The species is known for its distinctive "conk-la-ree" song, a liquid, gurgling trill that is a familiar sound of wetlands and fields.
howToFind: Red-winged Blackbirds are common in wetland areas, marshes, and along the edges of ponds and lakes. Look for males perched on cattails, reeds, or nearby trees, often calling with their distinctive "conk-la-ree" song. In agricultural areas, they can be found in large flocks, especially during migration and winter. Visit wetland boardwalks or wildlife refuges for close views. Listen for their calls in roadside ditches and flooded fields. During breeding season, males are particularly conspicuous as they defend their territories with showy displays of their red epaulets.

shortDesc: Black and white duck with a red head.
longDesc: The Redhead is a medium-sized diving duck known for its distinctive appearance. Male Redheads sport a bright cinnamon-red head, black chest, and grayish body, creating a striking contrast. Females are more subdued with a warm brown coloration and a darker brown head. Both sexes have a blue-gray bill with a black tip and a noticeable sloping forehead profile. In flight, their wings make a whistling sound. The male's courtship call is a unique, cat-like "meow," while females produce a low, guttural quack.
howToFind: Redheads are diving ducks typically found on large, open bodies of water. Look for them on lakes, reservoirs, and bays, often in mixed flocks with other diving ducks. During migration, check flooded fields and smaller ponds. They're more likely to be seen in deeper waters than in shallow marshes. Use a spotting scope to scan for their distinctive rusty-red heads and gray bodies. Listen for their cat-like "meow" call, though they're generally quiet. Wildlife refuges and managed wetlands are good places to spot Redheads, especially during winter in their southern range.

shortDesc: Do you think of rhinos when you see this bird?
longDesc: Despite its name, the Rhinoceros Auklet is actually more closely related to puffins. This stocky seabird is characterized by its dark upper parts and lighter underside. During breeding season, adults develop a small horn-like projection at the base of their bill, inspiring their unusual name. They also sport white plumes on their face, giving them a distinguished appearance. These birds are excellent swimmers and divers, using their wings to "fly" underwater in pursuit of small fish. Their call is a low, growling sound, rarely heard away from breeding colonies.
howToFind: To spot Rhinoceros Auklets, visit coastal areas along the North Pacific. Look for them on rocky offshore islands or flying low over the water, often in the early morning or late evening when they're commuting between nesting sites and feeding areas. During breeding season, take a pelagic birding trip for better chances of seeing them. Watch for their distinctive silhouette with a stout, orange bill. Listen for their low growling calls at nesting colonies. Outside of breeding season, scan the open ocean from coastal viewpoints, especially during stormy weather which might push them closer to shore.

shortDesc: It has its wedding ring on its mouth.
longDesc: The Ring-billed Gull is a medium-sized gull with a distinctive black ring around its yellow bill, from which it gets its name. Adults have a white head, neck, and underparts, with pale gray back and wings. Their legs are yellow-green. Immature birds are mottled brown, gradually acquiring adult plumage over three years. These gulls are highly adaptable and intelligent, known for their ability to thrive in urban environments. Their call is a loud, high-pitched "kree-aar," often heard in parking lots and beaches.
howToFind: Ring-billed Gulls are widespread and adaptable. Look for them near any body of water, including urban lakes, rivers, and coastal areas. They're also common in parking lots, parks, and sports fields, especially where people feed birds. Watch for them following fishing boats or congregating at landfills. During breeding season, visit large lakes where they nest in colonies. Their tendency to gather in large, noisy flocks makes them easy to spot. Listen for their distinctive laughing calls. In winter, check warmer urban areas where they often congregate.

shortDesc: If you fail to see a ring on its neck, your eyes are basically correct.
longDesc: The Ring-necked Duck is a small diving duck with a distinctive peaked head shape. Males have a black head, chest, and back, contrasting sharply with their gray flanks. Despite their name, the chestnut collar on their neck is rarely visible in the field. The most noticeable feature is their white ring near the tip of their blue-gray bill. Females are less striking, with a gray-brown plumage and a white eye ring. These ducks are strong divers, often submerging completely in search of aquatic plants and invertebrates.
howToFind: Despite their name, Ring-necked Ducks are easier to identify by their peaked head shape and bold white ring near the tip of the bill. Look for them on freshwater ponds, lakes, and slow-moving rivers, often in small flocks. They prefer areas with submerged vegetation. During migration, check flooded fields and small wetlands. Use a spotting scope to observe their diving behavior. Wildlife refuges and managed wetlands are excellent places to find them, especially during winter in their southern range. Listen for their soft purring calls, though they're generally quiet.

shortDesc: This pheasant gets bred and hunted, bred and hunted, bred and...
longDesc: The Ring-necked Pheasant is a large, colorful game bird originally introduced from Asia. Males are spectacularly adorned with a green-blue head, red face wattles, a white neck ring, and a body covered in golden-brown feathers with intricate black markings. They have a long, pointed tail and can reach up to 36 inches in length. Females are more subtly colored in mottled brown, providing excellent camouflage. The male's call is a loud, harsh "krok-kok," often accompanied by wing-flapping, especially during the breeding season.
howToFind: Ring-necked Pheasants prefer open country with a mix of grasslands, agricultural fields, and brushy areas. Look for them along field edges, in overgrown ditches, and near hedgerows, especially in the early morning or late afternoon. Males are often seen strutting in open areas during spring, while females tend to stay hidden in vegetation. Listen for the male's loud, harsh "krok-krok" call. Drive slowly along rural roads, scanning the roadside vegetation. They're also attracted to game bird feeders in appropriate habitat. During winter, look for them scratching for food in harvested cornfields or gathered in small groups in sheltered areas.

shortDesc: The vacuum cleaners of the cities.
longDesc: The Rock Pigeon, also known as the common pigeon, is a familiar sight in urban areas worldwide. These birds exhibit a wide variety of color patterns, but the typical "wild" type has a blue-gray body with two black wing bars and iridescent feathers on the neck. They have a plump body, small head, and short legs. Rock Pigeons are known for their cooing vocalizations and their remarkable homing abilities, which have been utilized by humans for centuries in pigeon racing and message delivery.
howToFind: Rock Pigeons, also known as city pigeons, are ubiquitous in urban environments. Look for them in city squares, parks, under bridges, and on building ledges. They're often seen walking on sidewalks or gathered in flocks where people feed birds. In more rural areas, check around barns, silos, and grain elevators. Listen for their soft cooing calls. Their tendency to gather in large groups and their comfort around humans make them one of the easiest birds to observe up close. Watch for their courtship displays, which involve puffing up their necks and strutting in circles.

shortDesc: Many shorebirds are among rocks, but this bird REALLY loves rocks!
longDesc: The Rock Sandpiper is a stocky shorebird with a distinctive appearance. In breeding plumage, they have heavily spotted and streaked upperparts in rich browns and black, with a paler belly. Their winter plumage is more subdued, with overall gray coloration. They have short, yellowish legs and a slightly decurved bill. Rock Sandpipers are known for their hardiness, being one of the northernmost wintering shorebirds in North America. Their call is a low, rolling "krrrr" or a sharp "pik."
howToFind: Rock Sandpipers are typically found along rocky coastlines in the North Pacific. Look for them foraging on wave-washed rocks, jetties, and breakwaters. They're often seen in small groups, probing for invertebrates among the seaweed and barnacles. During winter, they're one of the northernmost wintering shorebirds in North America. Visit coastal areas in Alaska or the Pacific Northwest, especially during stormy weather when they might be pushed closer to shore. Use a spotting scope to observe their feeding behavior on distant rocky outcrops. Listen for their low, purring calls.

shortDesc: A rock that has feathers...and moves!
longDesc: The Rock Wren is a small, active bird with a big personality. They have a grayish-brown upper body with fine white speckles, a pale eyebrow stripe, and a white-tipped tail. Their long, slightly curved bill is perfect for probing crevices for insects. Rock Wrens are known for their loud, varied songs, which can include over 100 different trills and notes. They have a unique habit of building "pavements" of small, flat stones leading to their nests.
howToFind: Rock Wrens inhabit dry, rocky areas throughout western North America. Look for them in boulder fields, canyon walls, rocky slopes, and even around old buildings or rock piles in more open country. They're often seen hopping and bobbing on rocks, frequently spreading their tails to show off white spots. Listen for their loud, ringing song, which can carry for quite a distance in their rocky habitat. Early morning is the best time to hear and see them. Watch for their distinctive behavior of placing small, flat rocks in front of their nest cavities. In desert areas, check around rocky outcrops and dry washes.

shortDesc: How does a beautiful hawk get named after its legs?
longDesc: The Rough-legged Hawk is a large, Arctic-breeding raptor known for its feathered legs, which extend to its toes (hence the name "rough-legged"). They exhibit two color morphs: light and dark. Light morphs have pale heads and dark belly patches, while dark morphs are overall dark brown. In flight, they're recognizable by the dark patches at their wrists and their feathered legs. These hawks are known for their ability to hover while hunting, similar to a kestrel. Their call is a cat-like mew, though they're generally quiet outside of the breeding season.
howToFind: Rough-legged Hawks are winter visitors to open country across much of North America. Look for them perched on utility poles, fence posts, or trees in wide-open areas like prairies, fields, and airport edges. They often hover while hunting, so watch for this distinctive behavior over open grasslands. Use a spotting scope to observe their feathered legs, which give them their name. During migration, visit hawk watch sites. In their winter range, drive through open agricultural areas, scanning for their large, bulky silhouettes. Listen for their cat-like mew calls, though they're generally quiet.

shortDesc: As stated, it has a ruby crown.
longDesc: The Ruby-crowned Kinglet is a small, active bird with olive-green plumage, one white wingbar with a black bar behind it, and a white eyering. The male's ruby crown patch is usually hidden, visible only when the bird is excited. These birds are known for their cheerful, complex song, which changes when they migrate to breeding grounds. They often hover while foraging for insects in dense foliage.
howToFind: Ruby-crowned Kinglets are tiny, active birds found in a variety of wooded habitats. Look for them flitting quickly through the outer branches of trees and shrubs, often at eye level or above. They're constantly on the move, so listen for their distinctive two-part call, a harsh "ji-dit" followed by a jumbled warble. During migration, they can be found in mixed-species foraging flocks. Watch for their characteristic wing-flicking behavior as they search for small insects. Males only show their ruby crown when excited, so be patient and observant. Check coniferous and mixed forests, as well as woodland edges and parks, especially during spring and fall migration.

shortDesc: Brown duck with a bright blue bill. and black-and-white head.
longDesc: The Ruddy Duck is a small, stout-bodied waterfowl with a distinctive appearance. Breeding males are unmistakable with their bright rusty-red body plumage, black crown, and large, powder-blue bill. Perhaps their most striking feature is their stiff, spiky tail, often held upright while swimming. Females and non-breeding males are more subdued, with grayish-brown bodies and a dark horizontal stripe across their otherwise pale cheeks. Their small size and chunky build give them a comical, almost toy-like appearance on the water. Ruddy Ducks are generally quiet, but during courtship, males produce a unique sound by rapidly tapping their bill against their neck feathers, creating a hollow "tik-tik-tik-tik-terr" noise.
howToFind: Ruddy Ducks prefer shallow, marshy ponds and lakes with plenty of emergent vegetation. Look for their distinctive stiff-tailed silhouette, often with the tail cocked upright. They're diving ducks, so watch for them suddenly disappearing and reappearing on the water's surface. During breeding season, males display their bright blue bills and chestnut bodies. Visit wildlife refuges, managed wetlands, and sewage treatment ponds for good viewing opportunities. Use a spotting scope to observe their behavior from a distance. Listen for the male's unusual courtship display, which includes slapping his bill against his chest to create a dull thud.

shortDesc: Bright brown winged shorebird with black and white on head.
longDesc: The Ruddy Turnstone is a stout, brightly patterned shorebird with a distinctive appearance. In breeding plumage, it sports a bold black and white head pattern, rusty-red back, and black breast markings that contrast sharply with its white belly. Its short, slightly upturned black bill is perfectly adapted for its foraging habit of flipping over stones and debris. Non-breeding adults are duller but retain a similar pattern. Their stocky build and orange legs make them stand out among other shorebirds. Ruddy Turnstones have a variety of calls, including a staccato, rattling "kit-kit-kit" often given in flight.
howToFind: Ruddy Turnstones are typically found along rocky coastlines, jetties, and breakwaters. During migration, they can also be seen on sandy beaches and mudflats. Look for them foraging in small groups, often flipping over stones and seaweed in search of invertebrates - a behavior that gives them their name. They're active and conspicuous, with a distinctive patterned plumage that stands out among other shorebirds. Visit coastal areas during spring and fall migration for the best chances of seeing them. Listen for their short, rapid, rattling calls. Use a spotting scope to observe their feeding behavior from a distance on rocky shorelines.

shortDesc: A brownish grouse.
longDesc: The Ruffed Grouse is a robust, chicken-sized woodland bird known for its cryptic plumage and dramatic courtship displays. Its mottled brown, black, and gray feathers provide excellent camouflage against forest floors and understory. The bird's most distinctive feature is the dark ruff of feathers around its neck, which it can erect into a spectacular collar during courtship or when alarmed. Both sexes sport a small crest and a broad, banded tail that can be fanned out. While generally quiet, the male Ruffed Grouse produces a remarkable sound during courtship: a low-frequency "drumming" created by rapidly beating its wings against the air, which can be heard up to a quarter-mile away.
howToFind: Ruffed Grouse inhabit deciduous and mixed forests across northern North America. They're more often heard than seen, so listen for the male's characteristic drumming sound, produced by rapidly beating their wings. This sound is most frequent during spring but can be heard year-round. Look for them along hiking trails, old logging roads, and forest edges, especially early in the morning or late in the evening. They're often seen feeding on buds in trees or scratching for food on the forest floor. In winter, look for their tracks in the snow, which might lead you to areas where they feed or roost. Be alert for the explosive sound of their take-off if you flush one unexpectedly.

shortDesc: Orangish, brown hummingbird that summers here.
longDesc: The Rufous Hummingbird is a small but fiery jewel of the bird world, known for its aggressive nature and impressive long-distance migration. Males are unmistakable with their bright orange-red throat (gorget) and rusty-orange back and sides, which give the species its name. Females and immature birds are green above with rufous-washed flanks and often a spot of orange on the throat. Despite their tiny size—barely larger than a ping pong ball—Rufous Hummingbirds are known for their feisty temperament, often chasing away much larger birds from feeders. Their wings produce a distinctive low-pitched humming sound in flight, and males make a sharp, rising "zzzt" sound during their spectacular J-shaped courtship dives.
howToFind: Rufous Hummingbirds are feisty, migratory hummingbirds found in the western part of North America. During breeding season, look for them in open or shrubby areas within coniferous forests. They're often seen defending flowering patches or feeders aggressively. Listen for their buzzing wings and sharp, squeaky vocalizations. During migration, they can be found in a variety of habitats, including mountain meadows, parks, and backyard gardens. Set up hummingbird feeders or plant nectar-rich flowers to attract them. Watch for the male's brilliant orange-red throat and their acrobatic courtship displays. They're most active during early morning and late afternoon.

shortDesc: Gray thrasher with brown wings and brown dots on chest.
longDesc: The Sage Thrasher is a medium-sized songbird intimately associated with the sagebrush ecosystems of western North America. It has a slender, slightly curved bill and a long tail, typical of thrashers. Its plumage is predominantly grayish-brown above and white below, heavily streaked with dark spots on the breast and sides. A pale eyebrow stripe and dark cheek patch add character to its face. Despite its somewhat plain appearance, the Sage Thrasher is renowned for its beautiful and complex song, often described as a long series of warbled phrases punctuated with mimicry of other bird species. This impressive vocalization has earned it the nickname "Mountain Mockingbird."
howToFind: Sage Thrashers are closely associated with sagebrush habitats in the western United States. Look for them perched atop sagebrush or other desert shrubs, especially during the breeding season when males sing from exposed perches. They're often seen running along the ground between shrubs. Visit areas of extensive sagebrush, particularly in the early morning when they're most vocal. Listen for their complex, melodious song which can last for several minutes. During migration, they may appear in other open habitats with scattered shrubs. Watch for their habit of pumping their long tails downward while perched.

shortDesc: This bird clearly shows favoritism with regards to plants.
longDesc: The Sagebrush Sparrow is a small, handsome bird perfectly adapted to life in the arid sagebrush sea of the American West. It has a gray head with a distinctive white eye ring and "mustache" stripe, set off by a neat black malar stripe. The back is gray-brown, while the underparts are white with a single dark spot on the breast. This sparrow's long tail and ground-hugging habits give it a sleek, streamlined appearance as it runs between shrubs. The Sagebrush Sparrow's song is a series of clear, tinkling notes followed by a buzzy trill, often delivered from atop a sagebrush plant. Its call is a soft, metallic "tink."
howToFind: As their name suggests, Sagebrush Sparrows are closely tied to sagebrush habitats in the western United States. Look for them perched on top of sagebrush plants or running quickly between bushes on the ground. They're most easily spotted during the breeding season when males sing from exposed perches. Visit areas of extensive sagebrush early in the morning or in the evening when they're most active. Listen for their simple, tinkling song. They can be secretive, so patience is often required. During the non-breeding season, they may form small flocks, making them somewhat easier to spot as they forage on the ground.

shortDesc: If this is a sanderling, what is a sander?
longDesc: The Sanderling is a small, plump shorebird known for its energetic feeding behavior along ocean beaches. In breeding plumage, it has a rusty head, neck, and back, with white underparts. In winter, it molts to a pale gray above and white below, giving it a frosty appearance that stands out against dark sand. Its black bill and legs are relatively short for a sandpiper. Perhaps its most endearing feature is its feeding habit: Sanderlings are often seen chasing the receding waves on beaches, hurriedly picking at exposed sand before running from the incoming surf, creating a charming "wave dance." Their call is a short, sharp "plit" or "quit," often given in flight.
howToFind: Sanderlings are one of the easiest shorebirds to spot on sandy beaches. Look for small, pale shorebirds running in and out with the waves along the water's edge. They're often seen in small flocks, chasing the receding waves to pick up exposed invertebrates, then quickly retreating from incoming waves. Visit any sandy coastline during migration or winter. They're active and conspicuous, making them easy to observe even without binoculars. Listen for their quiet, rolling "plik plik" calls. During high tide, check wrack lines or sandier areas of mudflats where they may gather to roost.

shortDesc: Tall, gray crane with red forehead.
longDesc: The Sandhill Crane is a tall, stately bird with long legs, a long neck, and a distinctive profile. Adults are predominantly gray with a red forehead, white cheeks, and a long, pointed bill. Their large size—standing up to 4 feet tall with a wingspan of 6-7 feet—makes them one of the most impressive birds in North America. Sandhill Cranes are known for their elaborate courtship dances, involving bowing, jumping, and wing flapping. Their call is a loud, rattling bugle that can be heard from great distances, especially when amplified by the birds' unique elongated windpipe that coils into their sternum. This haunting call is one of the most ancient bird voices in the world.
howToFind: Sandhill Cranes are large, distinctive birds found in open habitats. During migration and winter, look for them in agricultural fields, wet meadows, and shallow marshes, often in large flocks. They're also known to gather at specific stopover sites during migration, where thousands can be seen at once. Listen for their loud, rattling bugle call, which can be heard from great distances. Early morning and late afternoon are the best times to see them flying to and from roosting sites. During breeding season, visit open wetlands and meadows in their northern range. Watch for their elaborate courtship dances, which involve jumping, bowing, and throwing objects into the air.

shortDesc: Another bird imported from Georgia.
longDesc: The Savannah Sparrow is a small, streaky sparrow with a distinctive appearance despite its overall brown coloration. It has a pale eyebrow stripe, often with a yellowish tinge in front of the eye, and a finely streaked breast with a small, dark central spot. The back is brown with darker streaks, and the tail is relatively short for a sparrow. While coloration can vary across its wide range, the combination of fine breast streaking, pale eyebrow, and often yellowish face markings helps distinguish it from other sparrows. The Savannah Sparrow's song is a high, buzzy trill that usually starts with two or three high notes, often described as "sip-sip-sip-zeeee-zay-zay."
howToFind: Savannah Sparrows inhabit open grasslands, meadows, and agricultural fields. Look for them perched on fence posts, low shrubs, or grass stems, especially during the breeding season when males sing from exposed perches. They often run along the ground, so scan open areas carefully. Listen for their distinctive buzzy song that typically ends with two higher pitched notes. Visit coastal marshes, prairies, and airfields, particularly in the early morning or late afternoon. During winter, they may form small flocks in weedy fields or along the edges of marshes. Watch for their habit of pumping their tails while perched or walking.

shortDesc: Brownish phoebe with a reddish belly
longDesc: The Say's Phoebe is a charming flycatcher of the western United States, known for its subtle beauty and gentle demeanor. It has a pale gray-brown upper body, slightly darker wings and tail, and a distinctively pale peachy-orange belly. The head is slightly darker than the body, creating a subtle contrast. Its bill is black and its legs are dark. One of its most endearing behaviors is the characteristic tail wagging, a gentle side-to-side motion often seen when the bird is perched. The Say's Phoebe's voice is a plaintive, descending "pee-yeer," often given from an exposed perch.
howToFind: Say's Phoebes prefer open, arid habitats in western North America. Look for them perched on low structures like fences, rocks, or shrubs in open country. They're often seen making short flights to catch insects, then returning to the same or a nearby perch. Visit desert scrublands, grasslands with scattered trees, or open farmland. They're also fond of human structures and can be found around barns, bridges, and buildings. Listen for their plaintive, whistled "pee-er" call. During breeding season, check under the eaves of buildings or on cliff ledges for their mud and grass nests. They're active during daylight hours but are especially visible in the early morning and late afternoon.

shortDesc: Sandpiper with white belly and chest, as well as brown wings and hat.
longDesc: The Semipalmated Sandpiper is a small shorebird, part of a group often referred to as "peeps" due to their diminutive size. In breeding plumage, it has a brown and black streaked back, white underparts, and a dark cap. Non-breeding birds are overall grayer. It has a short, straight black bill and black legs. The "semipalmated" in its name refers to the partial webbing between its toes, though this feature is rarely visible in the field. These sandpipers are notably gregarious, often seen in large flocks during migration. Their call is a soft, lisping "churt" or "cheet," often given in flight.
howToFind: Semipalmated Sandpipers are typically found along coastlines, mudflats, and the edges of ponds and lakes during migration. Look for small flocks of these tiny shorebirds probing the mud with their short bills. They often mix with other small sandpipers, so careful observation is needed. Visit coastal areas, estuaries, and inland wetlands during spring and fall migration. Use a spotting scope to observe their feeding behavior from a distance. Listen for their quiet, rolling "churt" call. During high tide, check wrack lines or sandier areas where they may gather to roost. Early morning and late afternoon are often the best times to see them actively foraging.

shortDesc: A hawk that has bluish gray wings, red-and-white chest, and red eyes.
longDesc: The Sharp-shinned Hawk is a small, agile raptor known for its incredible speed and maneuverability in forest environments. Adults have a slate-gray back, rusty barred underparts, and a dark cap that contrasts with their pale nape. Juveniles are brown above with streaky underparts. One of their most distinctive features is their relatively small head, short rounded wings, and long, square-tipped tail. In flight, they alternate between quick flapping and short glides. The Sharp-shinned Hawk is often silent, but during breeding season may give a high, thin "kik-kik-kik" call.
howToFind: Sharp-shinned Hawks are forest-dwelling birds that are often seen during migration. Look for them at hawk watch sites during spring and fall, where they can be seen in good numbers on days with favorable winds. In forested areas, watch for their quick, agile flight as they maneuver through trees hunting for small birds. They're also known to visit backyard bird feeders in pursuit of prey. Listen for alarm calls from small birds, which often indicate a Sharp-shinned Hawk is nearby. During breeding season, visit dense coniferous or mixed forests and listen for their high-pitched "kik-kik-kik" calls. Be patient and scan the mid-canopy carefully, as they can be secretive.

shortDesc: Sandpiper that has a shorter bill than the Long-billed Dowitchers.
longDesc: The Short-billed Dowitcher is a medium-sized shorebird with a long, straight bill—despite its name, the bill is only "short" in comparison to its close relative, the Long-billed Dowitcher. In breeding plumage, it has intricate reddish underparts and a mottled brown back. Non-breeding birds are predominantly gray. Its legs are yellowish-green, which can be a helpful identification feature. The Short-billed Dowitcher feeds with a distinctive rapid up-and-down motion, likened to a sewing machine, probing deep into mud or shallow water. Its call is a mellow, flutelike "tu-tu-tu" or "kerwit," quite different from the sharper calls of many other shorebirds.
howToFind: Short-billed Dowitchers are typically found in coastal mudflats, salt marshes, and the edges of shallow ponds during migration. Look for them probing deeply in the mud with their long bills in a distinctive "sewing machine" motion. They often gather in small to medium-sized flocks. Visit coastal areas, estuaries, and shallow wetlands during spring and fall migration. Use a spotting scope to observe their feeding behavior from a distance. Listen for their distinctive flight call, a mellow, fluty "tu-tu-tu". During high tide, check for roosting flocks on higher ground near feeding areas. Early morning and late afternoon are often the best times to see them actively foraging.

shortDesc: Brown owl that has yellow eyes and small "ears".
longDesc: The Short-eared Owl is a medium-sized owl with a rounded head and barely visible ear tufts, which give it its name. It has a pale, streaked body with a barred tail and wings. Its facial disk is pale with prominent yellow eyes encircled by black, giving it a surprised expression. In flight, it shows a distinctive underwing pattern with dark wingtips and wrists. Unlike many owl species, Short-eared Owls are often active during daylight, especially late afternoon and early morning. Their flight is buoyant and moth-like, with deep, silent wingbeats. During courtship, males perform a rhythmic clapping of their wings beneath their body. Their voice is rarely heard but includes a series of hoarse barks or a catlike "keee-ow."
howToFind: Short-eared Owls inhabit open country such as grasslands, prairies, marshes, and tundra. Unlike many owls, they're often active during daylight, especially late afternoon and early evening. Look for them flying low over fields with a distinctive floppy, moth-like flight. They often perch on the ground or on low posts. Visit large open areas with high populations of small mammals, particularly at dusk or dawn. During winter, they may form communal roosts in grassy or weedy fields. Listen for their barking "voo-hoo-hoo" call or their wing-clapping display. Be patient and scan open areas carefully, as they can be well-camouflaged when perched on the ground.

shortDesc: White songbird with black wings and brown cheeks.
longDesc: The Snow Bunting is a striking bird of the far north, aptly named for its snowy white plumage and its comfort in cold, windswept landscapes. Breeding males are almost entirely white with black backs and wingtips. Females and non-breeding males are more buffy-brown on the back and head, but still show extensive white in the wings and body. In flight, Snow Buntings flash conspicuous white wing patches. They have a small, conical bill typical of seed-eating birds, and a slightly rounder body shape compared to many other songbirds. Their call is a soft, rolling trill, and their song (rarely heard outside the Arctic breeding grounds) is a series of clear, tinkling notes and trills.
howToFind: Snow Buntings are arctic-breeding birds that can be found in open, snowy fields across northern North America during winter. Look for flocks of white birds with black wingtips swirling over barren, windswept areas. They often feed on the ground in stubble fields, beaches, or along roadsides. Visit coastal dunes, airport fields, and large open agricultural areas in winter. Listen for their soft, tinkling calls as flocks move about. They're most active during daylight hours but can be especially visible in early morning and late afternoon. During migration and in winter, they often associate with other open-country birds like Horned Larks and Lapland Longspurs.

shortDesc: Medium-sized white goose with red bill.
longDesc: The Snow Goose is a large, distinctive waterfowl species known for its bright white plumage and black wing tips. There are two color morphs - the "white" morph, which is entirely white except for black wing tips, and the "blue" morph, which has a gray-blue body. Both morphs share the same black bill with pink, tooth-like serrations along the edges, which helps them graze on grasses and aquatic vegetation. Snow Geese are highly social birds and are often seen in large, noisy flocks, especially during migration. Their honking calls can be heard from a distance, adding to their presence in wetland habitats.
howToFind: Snow Geese are best found in large open areas such as agricultural fields, wetlands, and coastal marshes. During migration and winter, look for massive flocks that can number in the thousands, often creating a "blizzard" effect when they take flight. Visit wildlife refuges, particularly those along major flyways, during spring and fall migration. Listen for their raucous honking calls, which can be heard from great distances. Early morning and late afternoon are the best times to see them flying to and from roosting sites. In their arctic breeding grounds, look for them in tundra wetlands. Be prepared to differentiate between white and "blue" color morphs, which often occur in the same flocks.

shortDesc: Their presence graces Washington once every few years.
longDesc: The Snowy Owl is a majestic, large owl of the Arctic tundra, instantly recognizable by its striking white plumage. Adult males are often nearly pure white, while females and younger birds have varying amounts of dark barring on a white background. They have large, round heads with no ear tufts, piercing yellow eyes, and feathered feet adapted for the cold Arctic environment. Their massive size—they can have a wingspan up to 5 feet—makes them one of the largest owls in North America. Unlike many owl species, Snowy Owls are diurnal, often active during daylight hours. They are generally silent away from their breeding grounds, but may occasionally give a deep, raspy "kroo-kroo" call or a harsh, grating shriek when alarmed.
howToFind: Snowy Owls are arctic birds that sometimes irrupt into southern Canada and the northern United States during winter. Look for them in wide-open areas that resemble their tundra habitat, such as coastal dunes, airport fields, and large agricultural areas. They often perch conspicuously on the ground or on low posts, making them easier to spot than many owl species. Visit coastal areas, large open fields, and even urban areas during winter irruptions. They're active during daylight hours, so scanning open areas carefully throughout the day can be productive. Listen for their low, raspy hoots, though they're often silent. Be respectful and maintain a safe distance, as these owls can be stressed by human disturbance.

shortDesc: A plover that nests in the Pacific coast.
longDesc: The Snowy Plover is a small, pale shorebird with a distinctively dainty appearance. It has a pale gray-brown back, white underparts, and a white forehead with a dark patch on either side of its neck. During breeding season, males develop a black forehead bar and ear patches. Its legs are dark, and its bill is slender and black. One of its most charming features is its large, dark eyes that seem oversized for its small head. Snowy Plovers have a habit of running in short bursts and then stopping abruptly, a behavior that can help in identifying them. Their call is a soft, whistled "tu-lee" or "too-lee," often given in flight.
howToFind: Snowy Plovers inhabit sandy beaches, alkaline flats, and salt pans. Look for these small, pale plovers running along the upper parts of beaches or around the edges of salt pans. They blend in well with their surroundings, so careful scanning is necessary. Visit wide, sandy beaches or inland salt flats, especially during breeding season. Listen for their soft, whistled "poo-he" call. They're active throughout the day but may be easier to spot in early morning or late afternoon when there's less human disturbance. During breeding season, be cautious of nest areas, which are often just shallow scrapes in the sand. Use binoculars or a spotting scope to observe them from a distance to avoid disturbing these sensitive birds.

shortDesc: This sparrow is a master composer.
longDesc: The Song Sparrow lives up to its name with the male's ability to learn up to 20 different songs, with as many as 1,000 variations in its lifetime. This medium-sized sparrow has a variable appearance across its range, but in the Northwest, it typically sports a russet-brown and gray plumage with bold streaks down its breast. These streaks often converge to form a distinctive central spot. A gray eyebrow stripe adds character to its face. Despite regional variations, the Song Sparrow's rich, musical trill remains a constant, brightening gardens and fields alike.
howToFind: Song Sparrows are adaptable birds found in a variety of habitats, from backyard gardens to wetland edges. Look for them in brushy areas, along the margins of ponds and streams, and in overgrown fields. They often perch on exposed branches to sing, especially during breeding season. Visit parks, nature trails, and even residential areas with suitable habitat. Listen for their complex, melodious song, which varies regionally but typically starts with a few clear notes followed by a musical trill. They're active throughout the day but are especially vocal in the early morning. During winter, they may gather in small flocks in weedy fields or brush piles. Watch for their habit of pumping their tails while flying or perching.

shortDesc: Black grouse with orange eyelashes and yellow throat that shows through feathers during breeding season
longDesc: The Sooty Grouse is a large, chunky grouse of the coniferous forests of western North America. It has a overall dark gray to blackish plumage, giving it a "sooty" appearance that matches its name. Males have a yellow to orange comb over each eye, which becomes more prominent during breeding season. They also have a patch of bare, red skin on the neck that inflates during courtship displays. Females are more cryptically colored with brown and gray mottling for better camouflage. One of the most distinctive features of the Sooty Grouse is its deep, resonant hooting call, which males use to attract mates. This low-frequency "woop" can carry for long distances through the forest and is often the best way to locate these birds.
howToFind: Sooty Grouse inhabit coniferous and mixed forests in western North America. During breeding season, listen for the male's deep, booming hoots, which can carry for long distances through the forest. Look for them on the ground in forest openings or along trails, or perched in conifers. They're often more easily heard than seen. Visit montane forests in spring and early summer when males are most vocal. In late summer and fall, they may move to higher elevations to feed on berries and conifer needles. Watch for them dust bathing on forest roads or scratching in the leaf litter. Be patient and move quietly, as they can be secretive and well-camouflaged against the forest floor.

shortDesc: A sea bird that is darkish brown.
longDesc: The Sooty Shearwater is a large seabird known for its incredible long-distance migrations. It has long, narrow wings and a streamlined body adapted for efficient flight over vast ocean expanses. As its name suggests, the bird's plumage is predominantly dark sooty-brown, appearing almost black at a distance. The underwings are silvery, creating a distinctive flashing effect as the bird banks and turns in flight. Its bill is long, thin, and dark, with tubular nostrils adapted for excreting excess salt. Sooty Shearwaters are usually silent at sea, but on their breeding grounds they produce an eerie, wailing call. Their flight is characterized by long glides on stiff wings, punctuated by several quick wingbeats, a typical shearwater pattern.
howToFind: Sooty Shearwaters are pelagic seabirds best seen from the coast or on boat trips. Look for them skimming low over the waves with stiff wings, often in large numbers. They're most common along the Pacific Coast during their non-breeding season (our summer). Take a pelagic birding trip for the best chances of close views. From shore, scan the ocean with a spotting scope, especially on windy days when they might be pushed closer to land. Watch for their distinctive flight pattern: several quick wingbeats followed by a glide. They're often seen in mixed flocks with other seabirds. Listen for their harsh, croaking calls at breeding colonies, though they're usually silent at sea.

shortDesc: Solitary bird that is mostly brown with a yellow bill and black surrounding bill.
longDesc: The Sora is a small, secretive rail that inhabits freshwater marshes across much of North America. It has a compact body with a short, chicken-like bill that is yellow and triangular in shape. Its plumage is predominantly gray and brown, with black and white barring on the flanks. Adults have a distinctive black face mask and throat. One of its most striking features is its short, upturned tail, often held upright, showing off white undertail coverts. Soras are more often heard than seen, with a distinctive descending whinny call and a sharp, clear "ker-wee" whistle. Their calls are particularly frequent during breeding season and can often be heard day and night.
howToFind: Soras are secretive rails that inhabit freshwater marshes and wet meadows. They're more often heard than seen, so listen for their distinctive descending whinny call or their "ker-wee" whistle. Look for them along the edges of wetlands, often partially hidden in dense vegetation. Visit wildlife refuges or other protected wetlands with boardwalks for the best viewing opportunities. They're most active in early morning and late evening, when they may venture out into more open areas to feed. During migration, they can turn up in unusual places like small urban ponds. Be patient and scan carefully through gaps in the vegetation. Playing a recording of their call (responsibly and sparingly) may draw them into view.

shortDesc: You will likely never spot this :(.
longDesc: The Spotted Owl is a medium-sized owl famous for its association with old-growth forests in western North America. It has a round head without ear tufts, dark brown eyes, and brown plumage liberally spotted with white on the back, head, and underparts. The spots are larger and more numerous than in most other owls, giving the bird its name. The facial disk is pale with concentric brown rings, creating a distinctive target-like pattern. Spotted Owls are known for their low, deep hooting call, typically a series of four hoots with the middle two closer together, often described as "hoo, hoo-hoo, hooo." They also produce a variety of whistles, barks, and screams, particularly during the breeding season.
howToFind: Spotted Owls are rare and threatened birds that inhabit old-growth forests. Finding them requires careful planning and often the help of local experts or guided tours. They're strictly nocturnal, so night visits to known territories are necessary. Listen for their series of four-note hoots, which they use to communicate with mates and mark territory. Visit protected old-growth forest areas, particularly in the Pacific Northwest or California. During the day, they roost in dense foliage or tree cavities, making them very difficult to spot. Respect any restrictions or guidelines in place to protect these sensitive birds. Never use playback or artificial light to attract Spotted Owls, as this can disrupt their behavior and breeding success.

shortDesc: Sandpiper with spots on white belly
longDesc: The Spotted Sandpiper is a small shorebird with a distinctive appearance and behavior. In breeding plumage, it has bold black spots on its white underparts, while its back is brown with a slight greenish tinge. Non-breeding adults and juveniles lack the spots but retain the overall shape and behavior. They have a relatively long body, short neck, and tail that often bobs up and down as they walk. Their bills are orange with a dark tip, and their legs are pale pink to orange. One of the most recognizable features of the Spotted Sandpiper is its unique, stiff-winged flight style and its habit of constantly bobbing its tail up and down when standing or walking. Their call is a clear, piercing "peet-weet" often given in flight.
howToFind: Spotted Sandpipers can be found along the edges of various water bodies, including streams, lakes, and coastal areas. Look for their distinctive teetering motion as they walk along shorelines. During breeding season, watch for their spotted belly, which gives them their name. Visit rocky or sandy shorelines, especially those with some vegetation nearby. They're often seen alone or in pairs, unlike many other sandpipers that flock together. Listen for their clear "peet-weet" call. They're active during daylight hours, often seen flying low over water with rapid wingbeats. During migration, they can turn up at almost any water body, including small ponds and drainage ditches.

shortDesc: Sparrow that looks pretty close to a robin except with a red eye
longDesc: The Spotted Towhee is a striking bird of the western brushlands, larger than most sparrows and full of character. Males are a study in contrast, with gleaming black upperparts spotted and striped with brilliant white, set off by warm rufous flanks. Females share a similar pattern but replace the black with a rich charcoal gray. Both sexes sport ruby-red eyes that seem to glow against their dark heads. Their call is a distinctive cat-like mew, while their song is a loud, ringing "drink-your-tea!"
howToFind: Spotted Towhees inhabit brushy areas, woodland edges, and chaparral. Look for them scratching in leaf litter under dense shrubs, often in pairs. They frequently hop backwards while scratching, creating a distinctive rustling sound. Visit parks, nature trails, and overgrown gardens with suitable habitat. Listen for their cat-like "mew" call or their loud, musical trill song. Males often sing from exposed perches, especially during breeding season. They're active throughout the day but are especially vocal in the early morning. Watch for their habit of flicking their long tails as they move through undergrowth. In more open areas, they may perch on low branches, providing better viewing opportunities.

shortDesc: Brown-and-black grouse with red around eye
longDesc: The Spruce Grouse is a medium-sized grouse of the boreal forests of North America. Males have a striking appearance with predominantly dark gray to black plumage, accented by a red comb over the eye and a black throat bordered by white. Their tail feathers are tipped with a broad chestnut band. Females are more cryptically colored with mottled brown and white plumage, providing excellent camouflage among forest understory. Both sexes have feathered legs adapted for walking on snow. Spruce Grouse are known for their unusually tame behavior, often allowing close approach, which has unfortunately earned them the nickname "fool hen." Their vocalizations include soft clucks and whooshing sounds made by males during courtship displays.
howToFind: Spruce Grouse inhabit coniferous forests, particularly those dominated by spruce and fir. They're often remarkably tame, earning them the nickname "fool hen." Look for them on the ground in forest openings or along trails, or perched in conifers feeding on needles. Visit boreal forests in the northern U.S. and Canada, moving quietly along forest roads or trails. They're active during daylight hours but may be more visible in early morning or late afternoon. Listen for the male's wing-clapping display during breeding season. In winter, watch for their tracks in the snow, which might lead you to roosting or feeding areas. Be patient and scan carefully, as their mottled plumage provides excellent camouflage against the forest floor.

shortDesc: Its appearance is...stellar.
longDesc: The only western jay with a crest, the Steller's Jay has a black or charcoal head with a large, pointed crest and iridescent dark blue body, wings, and tail. Like many other jays, its voice is very loud, and it often imitates Red-tailed Hawk calls.
howToFind: Steller's Jays are striking birds of western coniferous and mixed forests. Look for their bold blue and black plumage and distinctive crested head. They're often noisy and conspicuous, making them easier to locate than many forest birds. Visit montane forests, campgrounds, and picnic areas in the western U.S. and Canada. Listen for their harsh, scolding calls and their ability to mimic other birds and even some mammals. They're active throughout the day and are often attracted to bird feeders in appropriate habitat. Watch for them caching food items, a behavior common to jays. During breeding season, they become more secretive but may still visit feeders regularly.

shortDesc: Surfs up!
longDesc: The Surf Scoter is a sea duck with a distinctive and somewhat comical appearance. Males are mostly black with a bulbous, multicolored bill that has earned them the nickname "skunk-headed coot." The bill is white and red at the base with a large black spot near the base, and the forehead and nape are white, contrasting sharply with the black body. Females are dark brown with pale cheek patches and a less swollen bill. Both sexes have a unique sloping forehead profile. In flight, Surf Scoters show dark wings without the white wing patches seen in some other scoter species. Their calls are rarely heard away from breeding grounds but include a low, gurgling whistle.
howToFind: Surf Scoters are sea ducks best found along coastal areas, particularly during winter and migration. Look for them in bays, estuaries, and just beyond the surf line along ocean beaches. They're often seen in small flocks, diving for mollusks and crustaceans. Visit coastal areas with a spotting scope for the best views. During breeding season, they move to freshwater lakes in the boreal forest and tundra. Listen for their weak, gurgling whistles, though they're generally quiet. They're active during daylight hours, often seen flying low over the water in loose lines. During rough weather, they may move into more sheltered waters, providing better viewing opportunities.

shortDesc: They live close to rocky shorelines. They love the surf.
longDesc: The Surfbird is a stocky shorebird with a distinctive appearance. In breeding plumage, it has a mottled gray and white upperpart pattern, with dark chevrons on its white underparts. Non-breeding adults are plainer gray above and white below. Year-round, Surfbirds have short yellow legs and a short, stout, dark bill. Their wings show a thin white stripe in flight. One of their most notable features is their habit of foraging in the splash zone of rocky coasts, often allowing waves to wash over them as they search for food – a behavior that gives them their name. Surfbirds are usually quiet, but during the breeding season, males give a rattling, chirping song.
howToFind: Surfbirds are typically found along rocky coastlines, often in the splash zone where waves crash against rocks. Look for them foraging in small groups, picking invertebrates from wet rocks and crevices. They blend in well with their rocky surroundings, so careful scanning is necessary. Visit rocky shorelines, jetties, and breakwaters along the Pacific Coast during migration and winter. Listen for their high-pitched, musical whistles. They're active throughout the day but may be easier to spot during low tide when more foraging habitat is exposed. During breeding season, they move to alpine tundra in Alaska and Yukon, where they're much harder to find. Use a spotting scope for close views without disturbing their feeding.

shortDesc: Brown hawk with white belly and brown band on chest.
longDesc: The Swainson's Hawk is a large buteo hawk known for its long-distance migration and variable plumage. It has long, pointed wings and a slim body compared to other buteos. There are light and dark morphs, with many intermediate variations. Light morphs have a dark bib on a pale chest, dark flight feathers contrasting with lighter wings, and a pale throat. Dark morphs are entirely dark brown. All morphs show pale underwing coverts contrasting with dark flight feathers, creating a distinctive pattern in flight. Their tails are grayish with narrow dark bands. Swainson's Hawks have a plaintive, whistled "kreeeeer" call often given in flight.
howToFind: Swainson's Hawks inhabit open country, including prairies, grasslands, and agricultural areas. During breeding season, look for them perched on utility poles, fence posts, or isolated trees in open landscapes. They're often seen soaring on thermals, especially during migration when they form large kettles. Visit open areas in the western U.S. during summer, or watch for migrating flocks in spring and fall, particularly in the central flyway. Listen for their plaintive whistle. They're most active during daylight hours, with peak activity in morning and late afternoon. During migration, visit known hawkwatch sites for impressive views of large numbers moving south.

shortDesc: Plan brown-and-white thrush, but beautiful song.
longDesc: The Swainson's Thrush is a medium-sized songbird with a distinctive appearance and beautiful song. It has olive-brown upperparts and pale underparts with dark spots on the chest. One of its most notable features is a bold buffy eye-ring and light-colored "spectacles" extending behind the eye. Its bill is relatively thin and dark. Swainson's Thrushes are more often heard than seen, with a song that is an ethereal, flute-like spiral of ascending notes. Their call is a distinctive "whit" or "peep" often given in flight or when alarmed.
howToFind: Swainson's Thrushes inhabit mature forests, both coniferous and deciduous. They're more often heard than seen, so listen for their distinctive upward-spiraling, flute-like song, especially at dawn and dusk. Look for them in the mid to lower canopy or on the forest floor, where they forage for insects and berries. Visit wooded areas with a dense understory, particularly during migration when they can be found in a variety of woodland habitats. They're most active in low light conditions, so early morning and evening are the best times for observation. During migration, they may be seen in city parks and wooded suburban areas. Watch for their habit of raising and lowering their wings slowly when agitated.

shortDesc: A solitary bird that is gray -- Do those two things mean it's depressed?
longDesc: The Townsend's Solitaire is a unique thrush with a distinctive appearance and behavior. It has a slender body with a long tail and is predominantly gray in color. Its most striking features are a white eye ring, white outer tail feathers that flash in flight, and a buffy wing patch visible when perched. Despite being a member of the thrush family, its appearance and behavior are more reminiscent of flycatchers. The Townsend's Solitaire has a beautiful, flutelike song consisting of a series of clear, ringing notes. Its call is a clear, whistled "veer," often given in flight.
howToFind: Townsend's Solitaires inhabit coniferous forests in mountainous areas. During breeding season, look for them perched conspicuously on treetops or snags, often delivering their beautiful, flutelike song. In winter, they move to lower elevations and can be found in juniper woodlands or other areas with abundant berries. Visit montane forests, particularly those with open areas or clearings. Listen for their variable songs and calls, which can be heard throughout the day. They're often seen making short, flycatcher-like flights to catch insects. During winter, watch for them defending berry-rich territories, which they may guard aggressively against other birds. They're active throughout the day but are especially vocal in the early morning.

shortDesc: A beautiful yellow warbler with different dark patterns on face and belly
longDesc: The Townsend's Warbler is a striking songbird, adorned with a vibrant palette that makes it a jewel of the forest canopy. Males sport a deep black cap and mask, contrasted sharply by a brilliant yellow face and chest. Their backs are a rich olive-green, complemented by bold black streaking on the flanks and two prominent white wing bars. Females and immature birds show a softer version of this pattern, with a more olive-colored cap and less distinct facial markings. The bird's song is a high, buzzy trill that descends in pitch, often described as "bzee-bzee-bzee-bzee," while its call is a sharp, high-pitched "tsit."
howToFind: Look for Townsend's Warblers in coniferous forests, particularly in the canopy of tall trees. During migration, they can be spotted in mixed-species flocks in lower vegetation. Listen for their high-pitched, buzzy song, often delivered from the treetops. In winter, search for them in parks and gardens with evergreen trees. They're active foragers, so watch for quick movements as they glean insects from needles and twigs. Birders often locate them by sound first, then use binoculars to spot their distinctive yellow and black plumage among the foliage.

shortDesc: Take a guess where it makes its nest.
longDesc: Tree Swallows have an iridescent blue-green back and white underparts; their dark cap extends down over the eye. Their voice is a charming, liquid twittering. These birds are insect feeders and can be seen gliding over waterbodies chasing small insects (including mosquitos); when insects are scarce, they'll feed on berries.
howToFind: Tree Swallows are often seen near water bodies, open fields, and meadows. Look for them swooping gracefully over lakes, ponds, and marshes as they catch insects in flight. During breeding season, check nest boxes and tree cavities near open areas, as they readily use artificial nest sites. Watch for their iridescent blue-green backs gleaming in the sunlight as they perch on wires or dead branches. In late summer and fall, scan power lines and dead snags for large flocks gathering before migration. Their liquid, chirping calls and aerial acrobatics make them a joy to observe in flight.

shortDesc: A rare black bird around Washington.
longDesc: The Tricolored Blackbird is a striking bird with a unique color pattern that sets it apart from other blackbirds. Males are glossy black overall, with a bright red shoulder patch bordered by a distinctive white stripe, creating the tricolored effect that gives the species its name. Females are more subdued, with dark brown plumage and faint streaking. Their call is a nasal, buzzy "konk-la-lee" or "oak-a-lee," often given in chorus when in large flocks. These birds are highly social, forming some of the largest breeding colonies of any North American landbird, sometimes numbering in the tens of thousands.
howToFind: To spot Tricolored Blackbirds, focus on freshwater marshes, agricultural fields, and grasslands in California's Central Valley and coastal areas. Look for large, noisy colonies, often mixed with other blackbird species. During breeding season, visit cattail or thistle marshes where they nest in dense colonies. Listen for their distinctive "konk-la-ree" call, similar to but more nasal than that of the Red-winged Blackbird. In winter, search for foraging flocks in open grasslands and agricultural areas. Their habit of forming dense, swirling flocks makes them an impressive sight when taking flight or settling to roost.

shortDesc: If this bird was an albino, you would never know.
longDesc: The Trumpeter Swan is North America's largest native waterfowl and one of its most majestic. This impressive bird is entirely white, with a long, graceful neck and a large, black bill. The bill often has a thin red border along the base, though this can be difficult to see at a distance. Young swans (cygnets) are gray and gradually whiten with age, reaching full adult plumage at 2-3 years old. Despite their size, Trumpeter Swans are capable of swift, powerful flight, their wings producing a rhythmic whooshing sound. Their voice is a deep, resonant, trumpet-like call — hence their name — which can be heard from a considerable distance. This call is often described as a loud, low-pitched "oh-OH," with the second syllable emphasized.
howToFind: Trumpeter Swans prefer shallow wetlands, ponds, lakes, and slow-moving rivers with abundant aquatic vegetation. During breeding season, look for them in remote freshwater marshes and lakes in Alaska, western Canada, and parts of the northwestern United States. In winter, they congregate in ice-free areas, including some urban and suburban locations where they've become accustomed to human presence. Good places to spot them include wildlife refuges, large parks with suitable water bodies, and agricultural fields near water. The best times for observation are during winter and early spring before they depart for breeding grounds. Early mornings and late afternoons are ideal, as swans are often active during these times, feeding or flying between roosting and feeding sites. Listen for their distinctive trumpet-like calls, which can help locate them even in misty or foggy conditions. When observing Trumpeter Swans, maintain a respectful distance to avoid disturbing these magnificent birds, especially during the breeding season when they can be territorial.

shortDesc: This bird overgrew its eyelashes.
longDesc: The Tufted Puffin is a charismatic seabird, often called the "sea parrot" due to its distinctive appearance. During the breeding season, adults sport a thick, bright orange bill, a white face, and a black body. Their most striking feature is a pair of golden plumes that sweep back from their eyes, giving them their "tufted" name.
